If he removes the dust, then...
It's because of the light of wisdom.
Eight. wisdom doesn't illuminate without mind.
Without wisdom, the mind doesn't know.
Nine, the adventitious dust.
Even though it's exhausted.
In the first place, there's no coming or going.
Even though cognition arises and illuminates, it doesn't arise or cease.
There's also no arising or ceasing.
Ten, however, he attains the light of wisdom.
Then the nature of mind is perfectly still and illuminating.
The Dharma realm is clearly and insightfully illuminated.
It's ultimately pure.
Therefore, he knows that there's no cultivation of the myriad phenomena.
He sets out to cultivate them and then attains no cultivation.
Although the original nature is empty, it's revealed to be empty by cultivating emptiness.
it's also made apparent by cultivating emptiness.
This is recorded by the Zongjing.
There's a profound reason for it.
It's simply because sentient beings lack wisdom and don't cultivate it.
They fall into ignorance.
They don't illuminate the nature of their minds.
They fall into the cycle of transmigration in vain.
If they don't receive the wisdom light of the Zongjing, how can they reveal the treasures of their mind?
How can it be revealed as a treasure of the mind?
Moreover, the untainted wisdom nature of sentient beings is inherently possessed.
They are inherently endowed with it.
They're obscured by objective objects.
It's like a mirror that's obscured by dust.
But they can know that the mirror is originally clear.
That's when conscience ends, and the dust is exhausted.
Where the adventitious dust is ended.
true nature is clear.
As the Mahāparinirvāṇa-sūtra says.
"Suppose there's a large village outside.
There's a śāla forest.
In it, there's a tree.
It grows up before the forest does.
It's a hundred years old.
The owner of the forest then.
He poured water on it.
He fixed it up at the right time.
The tree aged and rotted.
Its skin, skin, branches, and leaves all fell off.
They all fell off.
Only the true remains.
The Tathāgata is likewise.
All the old stuff has been removed.
They've all been removed.
Only all true dharmas remain.
That's why the monk Yippo says in his song.
"For myriad generations, the golden wheel has been the noble prince.
'Only this is the true, spiritual enlightenment.'
Under the bodhi tree, he liberates sentient beings.
He liberates all sentient beings and escapes birth-and-death.
They don't undergo birth-and-death.
He's truly a great man.
Without form or characteristics, the great Vairocana ...
The dust and trouble cease, and true thusness remains.
It's a perfectly brilliant priceless pearl.
Axiom Mirror Record, Volume 13

source_sentence: 丙午歲分司大藏都監開板
translation: Opening of the Board of the Superintendent of the Grand Tripiṭaka for the Year of the Thirty-three
